CAP. XX.

An Adi to fufpend, until the Firft Day of May One thoufand eight hundred and feven, the Payment of all Drawbacks on Spirits made or diftilled in Great Britain or Irelandy and exported from either Country to the other refpeftively.

\_iyth. March 1807.]

f XTJTHEREAS by the Acts for the Union of Great Britain and t VV Ireland it is among ft other Things provided that any Articles ( of the Growth, Produce, or Manufacture of either Country which f are or may be fubject to internal Duty, or to Duty on the Materials f of which they are compofed, may be made fubject on their Importar

*	tion into each Country refpectively from the other, to fuch Counter-f vailing Duty as fhall appear to be juft and reasonable in refpect of 1 fuch internal Duty or Duties on the Materials, and that upon the

*	Export of the faid Articles from each Country to the other refpec-‘ tively, a Drawback (hall be given equal in Amount to the Counter*. < vailing Duty payable on fuch Articles on the Import thereof into

V.	And be it further enacted, That from and after the said First Day of may One Thousand eight hundred and seven, all Insurances whatsoever to be effected upon or in respect to any of the trading, dealing, carrying, removing, trans-shipping, or other Transactions by this Act prohibited, shall be also prohibited and declared to be unlawful; and if any of His Majesty's Subject's, or any Person or Persons resident within this United Kingdom, or within any of the Islands, Colonies, Dominions, or Territories thereunto belonging, or in His Majesty's Possession or Occupation, shall knowingly and willfully subscribe, effect, or make, or cause or procure to be subscribed, effected, or made, any such unlawful Insurances or Insurance, he or they shall forfeit and pay for every such Offence the Sum of One hundred Pounds for every such Insurance, and also Treble the Amount paid or agreed to be paid as the Premium of any such Insurance, the One Moiety thereof to the Use of His Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, and the other Moiety to the Use of any Person who shall inform, sue, and prosecute for the same.

VI.	Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend, or be deemed or construed to extend, to prohibit or render unlawful the dealing or trading in the Purchase, Sale, barter, or Transfer, or the carrying away or removing for the Purpose of being sold, transferred, used, or dealt with as Slaves, or the detaining or confining for the Purpose of being so carried away or removed, of any Slaves which shall be exported, carried, or removed from Africa, in any Ship or Vessel which, on or before the said First Day of may One thousand eight hundred and seven, shall have been lawfully cleared out from Great Britain according to the Law now in force for regulating the carrying of Slaves from Africa, or to prohibit or render unlawful the manning or navigating any such Ship or Vessel, or to make void any Insurance thereon, so as the Slaves to be carried therein shall be finally landed in the West Indies on or before the First Day of March One thousand eight hundred and eight, unless prevented by Capture, the Loss of the Vessel, by the Appearance of an Enemy upon the Coast, or other unavoidable Necessity, the Proof whereof shall lie upon the Coast, or other unavoidable Necessity, the proof whereof shall lie upon the Party charged; any Thing herein-before contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

Cap. xxxvi.

An Ad to enable His Majefty to veft the Sands of Traeth Mavur^ dividing the Counties of Carnarvon and Merioneth, in William Alexander Madocks Efquire.	[ill	Augnjl	1807.]

4 TT7HEREAS there is a certain Trad of Sands fituate on the 4 VV Elluary called Traeth-Mawr, dividing the Counties of Car-4 narvon and Merioneth, and extending from Pont Alerglajlyn to the 4 Point of Gefi, which in its prefent State,, is unproductive and inca-4 pable of being cultivated, and the Palfage over the fame is frequently 4 attended with great Inconvenience, Delay, -Difficulty, Expence, 4 and Danger: And Whereas, if the faid Sands were protected from 4 the Sea by Embankments and other neceffary Works, the fame might 4 be cultivated and rendered productive, and the Communication * between the faid Two Counties would be thereby greatly facilitated 4 and improved, and fuch Embankments and Works would alfo be 4 of publick Utility; but the making and maintaining of the fame £ will be attended with confiderable Difficulty and Expence : And 4 Whereas William Alexander Mado ks, of Tan yr A lit, in the County -4 of Carnarvon, Efquire, is defirous of conftruding and making 4 fuch Embankments, Sea Walls, Ramparts, Fences, Sluices, 4 Bridges, and other Works, as may be neceffary for protecting the 4 faid Sands from the Influx of the Sea, at his own Expence, on 4 having the fame veiled in him and his Heirs and Affigns in Fee 4 Simple: And Whereas His Majefty, in right of His Crown, 4 claims to be entitled to the faid Sands, and being defirous of 4 encouraging Undertakings of publick Utility, His Majefty has been c moll gracioufly pleafed to lignify his Royal Pleafure, that fo much 4 of the faid Trad of Sands from the Point of Ged to Pont Abcrglajlyn 4 afore faid, as fhall be protected from the Influx of the Sea, by the laid 4 Wi liam Alexander Madocks, his Heirs or Affigns, in Manner afore-4 faid, fhall (as far as His Majefty is interefted therein) be granted 4 and confirmed to, and veiled in the faid William Alexander Madocks, 4 his Heirs and Affigns, in Fee Simple:
